Bowing to the Buddha's feet, the compassionate World-Honored One, who for countless eons bore the sufferings of the many,
The afflictions already exhausted, the habits also removed, BrahmÄ, Indra, dragons and spirits all respectfully venerate.
Also bowing to the unsurpassed Dharma that illuminates the world, which can purify impurities and stop frivolous arguments,
That which is spoken by the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, and also the assembly of sages and saints.
The non-Buddhist says:
The verse says, That which is spoken by the World-Honored One. What is the World-Honored One?
The Buddhist says:
Why do you give rise to such doubts?
The non-Buddhist says:
Because there are various explanations of the characteristics of the World-Honored One, doubts arise.
Some people say:
The god Veá¹‡u-tathÄgata (meaning all-victorious) is called the World-Honored One.
Some also say:
The god MaheÅ›vara (meaning great self-mastery) is called the World-Honored One.
Some also say:
Sages such as Kapila, Uluka, and Kanada are all called World Honored Ones.
Why do you alone call the Buddha the World Honored One?
Therefore, doubts arise.
Internally, it is said:
The Buddha clearly and unobstructedly knows the true characteristics of all dharmas, and is also able to expound the profound and pure Dharma. Therefore, he alone is called the World Honored One.
Externally, it is said:
Other guides are also able to clearly understand the characteristics of dharmas and are also able to expound the profound and pure Dharma.

For example, the disciples of Kapila recite the SÄá¹ƒkhya scriptures, speaking of the general and specific characteristics of good dharmas. Among the twenty-five principles, the pure awareness part is called good dharma.

The disciples of Uluka recite the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika scriptures, saying that among the six principles, in the principle of seeking benefits, one should bathe three times a day and make offerings twice a day, and the combination of fire and so forth gives rise to the good dharma of the spiritual part.
The disciples of Kanada recite the NyÄya scriptures, saying that suffering practices such as bathing in five heats and pulling out hair are called good dharma.

There are also those who practice fasting, drowning in the abyss, jumping into fire, falling from high cliffs, silent standing, observing the cow precepts, and so on, which are considered good dharmas.
Such are all profound and pure dharmas. Why do you say only the Buddha can speak of them?
Internally, it is said:
These are all wrong views, because they cover the right view, and therefore cannot speak of the profound and pure Dharma.
This matter will be discussed in detail later.
Externally, it is said:
What are the characteristics of the good dharmas spoken by the Buddha?
Internally, it is said:
The Dharma of ceasing evil and practicing good.
The Buddha briefly speaks of two kinds of good dharmas:
The characteristics of cessation and the characteristics of practice.
Cessation of all evil is called the characteristic of cessation;
Cultivating all good is called the characteristic of practice.
What is evil?
Evil conduct of body, speech, and mind.
Body:
Killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct.
Speech:
False speech, divisive speech, harsh speech, and frivolous speech.
Mind:
Greed, hatred, and wrong views.

There are also those not included in the ten unwholesome paths, such as whipping, binding, and imprisoning, as well as various offenses before and after the ten unwholesome paths. This is called evil.
What is meant by cessation?
Cessation of evil and non-action.
Whether it arises in the mind, is spoken, or is accepted as a precept, from this day forth one will never commit it again. This is called cessation.
What is meant by good?
Right conduct of body, speech, and mind.
Such as welcoming, sending off, joining palms, and paying respects with the body.
Truthful speech, harmonious speech, gentle speech, and beneficial speech with the mouth.
Compassion and right views with the mind.
Various pure dharmas such as these are called good dharmas.
What is meant by practice?
Faithfully accepting and cultivating these good dharmas is called practice.
The outsider says:
Your sutra has a fault because it is not auspicious at the beginning, according to the sutra.
The masters who compose scriptures first speak of auspiciousness, so the meaning is easy to understand and the Dharma sound spreads.
If wise people read, recite, and contemplate it, they will attain increased longevity, majestic virtue, and respect.
There is a sutra called the Brahmadatta Sutra (meaning King of Vast Dominion), and such sutras all begin with auspicious.
Because it is auspicious at the beginning, it is also auspicious in the middle and end.
Your sutra begins with evil, so it is inauspicious.
Therefore, it is said that your sutra has faults.
Internally, it is said:
Otherwise,ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
In order to eliminate wrong views, this sutra is taught, which is auspicious.
This is inauspicious, this is the breath of wrong views, therefore there is no fault.
Furthermore, because there is no auspiciousness, this sutra, if there were a little auspiciousness, the beginning of the sutra should say auspicious.
This is truly without auspiciousness.
Why is it so?
This one thing is considered auspicious by some, inauspicious by others, or neither auspicious nor inauspicious by still others, because it is indefinite, there is no auspiciousness.
You foolish people, lacking skillful means, forcefully seek pleasure, vainly giving rise to thoughts, saying this is auspicious and that is inauspicious.
Next, because self, other, and both are not attainable, according to the sutra.
This auspicious dharma does not arise from itself.
Why is it so?
Because there is no dharma that arises from itself.
Also, because of the error of two characteristics, one is arising;
two is that which gives rise.
It also does not arise from other, because its own characteristic does not exist, and the characteristic of other also does not exist.
Moreover, because of infinite regress, because arising has further arising.
It also does not arise from both, because both are erroneous.
There are three kinds of arising dharmas:
self, other, and both.
Among these three kinds, it cannot be sought and obtained, therefore there is no auspicious matter.
The non-Buddhist says:ğŸ”½Because this auspiciousness arises from itself, it is like salt, according to the sutra.
It is like salt, whose nature is salty and can make other things salty.
auspiciousness is also like this, its own nature is auspicious and can make other things auspicious.
Internally, it is said:
Because it has already been refuted before, and also because the characteristics of salt reside within salt.
I have previously refuted the idea that dharmas arise from their own nature. Furthermore, your idea is that salt comes from causes and conditions, therefore salt is not salty by its own nature.
I do not accept your words. Now I will use your words to refute what you have said.
Although salt is combined with other things, those things do not become salt, because the characteristics of salt reside within salt.
It is like the characteristics of an ox not becoming the characteristics of a horse.
Externally, it is said:
Like a lamp.
It is like a lamp that illuminates itself and can also illuminate others.
Auspiciousness is also like this, it is auspicious by itself and can also make inauspicious things auspicious.
Internally, it is said:
Because a lamp has no darkness in itself or others.
A lamp has no darkness in itself.
Why is it so?
Because light and darkness do not coexist, a lamp also has no ability to illuminate.
Because it cannot illuminate, and also because of the error of two characteristics:
One is the illuminator, the other is the illuminated. Therefore, the lamp does not illuminate itself.
The place that is illuminated is also without darkness. Therefore, it cannot illuminate others.
Because it destroys darkness, it is called illumination. Since there is no darkness to be destroyed, it is not illumination.
The opponent says:
Because when it first arises, both [self and other] are illuminated.
I do not say that the lamp arises first and then illuminates. When it first arises, it illuminates itself and is also able to illuminate others.
The proponent of the treatise says:
This is not so.
Because the existence and non-existence of a single dharma cannot be apprehended.
When it first arises, half has arisen and half has not yet arisen.
What has arisen cannot illuminate, as explained above. How much less can what has not yet arisen illuminate anything?
Moreover, how can a single dharma both have characteristics and lack characteristics?
Moreover, because it does not reach darkness.
Whether the lamp has already arisen or has not yet arisen, it does not reach darkness, because their natures are mutually contradictory.
If the lamp does not reach the darkness, how can it illuminate the darkness?
The opponent says:
Like a spell and the stars, it is so.
If one recites a spell from afar, it can cause harm to a distant person;
It is also like the stars changing in the sky, causing misfortune for people.
The lamp is also like this, although it does not reach the darkness, it can illuminate the darkness.
The proponent of the inner teaching says:
Too much, because it is a fact.
If the lamp has the power to illuminate the darkness without reaching it, why doesn't it illuminate the darkness in China from being lit in India?
Like the power of a spell and the stars can reach far, but the lamp is not like this. Therefore your analogy is not correct.
Furthermore, if the beginning is auspicious, the rest is inauspicious.
If the beginning of the sutra is auspicious, the rest should be inauspicious.
If the rest is also auspicious, your statement that the beginning is auspicious is false.
The opponent says:ğŸ”½Because the beginning is auspicious, the rest is also auspicious.
Because the power of the auspicious beginning, the rest is also auspicious.
Because there are many inauspicious things, auspicious becomes inauspicious.
Your sutra says at the beginning that auspicious is mostly inauspicious, and because there are many inauspicious things, auspicious should become inauspicious.
The non-Buddhist says:
Like the hand of an elephant.
It is like an elephant being called having a hand because it has a hand, not because it has eyes, ears, head, etc.
In the same way, because of the power of a little auspiciousness, many inauspicious things are made auspicious.
The Buddhist says:
This is not so.
Because there is no fault of the elephant.
If the elephant is different from the hand, the head, feet, etc. are also different, then there is no separate elephant.
If the parts have the whole, why is there no foot in the head?
As explained in the refutation of difference.
If the elephant is not different from the hand, there is also no separate elephant.
If the parts are not different from the part, the head should be the foot, because the two are not different from the elephant, as explained in the refutation of oneness.
Such auspicious events cannot be sought through various causes and conditions. How can you say that because the beginning is auspicious, the middle and end are also auspicious?
The non-Buddhist says:
Stopping evil is wonderful, why not put it first?
The Buddhist says:
The practitioner must first know evil in order to be able to stop it, therefore evil comes first and stopping comes later.
The non-Buddhist says:
Good practice should come first, because it has wonderful results.

All good dharmas have wonderful results. The practitioner wants to attain wonderful results, so he stops evil. In this way, good practice should be explained first, and stopping evil should be explained later.
The Buddhist says:
Because of the sequential Dharma, first remove coarse defilements, then remove subtle defilements.
If the practitioner does not stop evil, he cannot cultivate good. Therefore, first remove coarse defilements, then dye good dharmas.
It is like washing clothes, first removing dirt, then it can be dyed.
The non-Buddhist says:
Having already explained stopping evil, you should not say good practice again.
The Buddhist says:
Because giving and other good practices are the sutras.
Giving is a good practice, not the cessation of evil.

Moreover, like a great bodhisattva, evil has already ceased, practicing the four immeasurables, pitying sentient beings and guarding others' lives, this is then a good practice, not the cessation of evil.
The non-Buddhist says:
Giving is the cessation of stinginess, therefore giving should be the cessation of evil.
The Buddhist says:
This is not so.
If not giving is indeed evil, then all who do not give should have offenses.
Moreover, for those who have exhausted the contaminants, stinginess has already been exhausted. When giving, what evil is being stopped?
There are people who, although practicing giving, do not stop stingy thoughts.
Even if they can stop it, it is still based on good practice. Therefore giving is a good practice.
The non-Buddhist says:
It has already been said to be good practice, it should not be said to be the cessation of evil.
Why is this?
Because the cessation of evil is precisely good practice.
The Buddhist says:
Because the characteristics of cessation and the characteristics of practice are mutually contradictory.
Therefore, when speaking of good practice, evil cessation is not included.
The opponent says:
This is indeed so.

I do not say that evil cessation and good practice are of the same characteristic, but evil cessation is precisely good dharmas. Therefore, if you speak of good practice, you should not also speak of evil cessation.
The proponent of the treatise says:
Evil cessation and good practice should be spoken of.
Why is this?
Evil cessation is called the cessation of all evils at the time of receiving precepts, and good practice is called the cultivation of good dharmas.

If only good practice and blessings are spoken of, but not evil cessation, there are people who receive precepts and cease evils, but when the mind is not good or neutral, at that time they are not practicing good, so there should be no blessings. At that time, because of the cessation of evil, there are also blessings.
Therefore, evil cessation should be spoken of, and good practice should also be spoken of.
This dharma of evil cessation and good practice is distinguished in three ways by the Buddha according to the intentions of the assembly:
The practice of giving, morality, and wisdom for the three types of people.
There are three types of practitioners:
Those of lower wisdom are taught to practice giving, those of middling wisdom are taught to practice morality, and those of higher wisdom are taught to practice wisdom.
Giving is defined as the thought associated with the relinquishment of wealth for the benefit of others,

And the arising of bodily and verbal actions. Morality is defined as the verbal expression, mental generation, and acceptance of precepts, from this day forth no longer engaging in the three types of sexual misconduct or the four types of verbal misconduct.
Wisdom is defined as the unwavering concentration of the mind on the characteristics of phenomena.
Why are they called lower, middling, and higher?
Because of the differences in benefits.
Giving is of lower benefit, this is called lower wisdom;
Morality is of middling benefit, this is called middling wisdom;
Wisdom is of higher benefit, this is called higher wisdom.
Furthermore, the rewards of giving are lower, the rewards of morality are middling, and the rewards of wisdom are higher, therefore they are called lower, middling, and higher wisdom.
The outsider said:
Is giving always of lower wisdom?
Internally said:
This is not so.
Why is it so?
There are two kinds of giving:
One is impure, the other is pure practice.
Impure giving is called the giving of a person of inferior wisdom.
Externally said:
What is called impure giving?
Internally said:
Giving in return is impure, like buying and selling, according to the sutras.
There are two kinds of rewards:
Immediate rewards and future rewards.
Immediate rewards are fame, respect, love, etc.
Future rewards are wealth and nobility in the next life, etc.
This is called impure giving.
Why is it so?
Because one still wants to receive.

It is like a merchant who travels far to other places, although he holds various goods and benefits many people, it is not out of compassion for sentient beings, but because he seeks his own profit, this karma is impure.
Giving in order to receive rewards is also like this.
Externally said:
What is called pure giving?
Internally said:
If a person loves and respects others and benefits them without seeking rewards in this world or the next,
such as the bodhisattvas and superior people who practice pure giving, this is called pure giving.
The non-Buddhist says:
Are all those who uphold the precepts not of middling wisdom?
The Buddhist says:
No, it is not so.
Why is it so?
There are two kinds of upholding the precepts:
one is impure, and the other is pure.
Those who uphold the precepts in an impure way are called people of middling wisdom.
The non-Buddhist says:
What is impure upholding of the precepts?
The Buddhist says:
Upholding the precepts while seeking pleasant rewards, for the sake of sexual desire, like practicing the sutras while concealing one's faults.
Pleasant rewards are of two kinds:
one is rebirth in the heavens, and the other is wealth and status among humans.
If one upholds the precepts while seeking rebirth in the heavens, to enjoy oneself with celestial maidens, or to experience the five desires among humans,
why is it so?
It is because of sexual desire.
Like one who covers up, internally desiring others' forms, externally pretending to be friendly, this is called impure upholding of precepts.
As Ananda said to Nanda:
Like rams butting each other, advancing yet retreating;
You uphold precepts for the sake of desire, the matter is also like this.
Although the body upholds precepts, the mind is dragged by desire,
This karma is impure, what use are these precepts?
The outsider said:
What is called pure upholding of precepts?
The insider said:

The practitioner thinks like this: all wholesome dharmas take precepts as the foundation. One who upholds precepts then has no remorse. Without remorse, there is joy. With joy, the mind is at ease. With an at-ease mind, one attains single-mindedness. With single-mindedness, one gives rise to true wisdom. With the arising of true wisdom, one attains disgust. With disgust, one attains detachment. With detachment, one attains liberation. With liberation, one attains nirvana.
This is called pure upholding of precepts.
The outsider said:
If the highest wisdom is for Udraka RÄmaputra and others, it is the highest sÅ«tra.
If a person of wisdom practices, he is called the highest wisdom.
Now Udraka RÄmaputra, Ä€rÄá¸a KÄlÄma, and other non-Buddhists should be people of the highest wisdom.
The inner [teachings] say:
This is not so.
Why is it so?
Wisdom is also of two kinds:
First, impure; second, pure.
The outer [teachings] say:
What is called impure wisdom?
The inner [teachings] say:
Because it is bound by the world, it is impure, like an enemy coming as a friend.
Worldly wisdom can increase birth and death.
Why is it so?
Because this wisdom binds again.
It is like an enemy who first pretends to be friendly, but after a long time, harm arises.
Worldly wisdom is also like this.
The outer [teachings] say:
Is it only wisdom that can increase birth and death?
Are giving and morality also like this?
The inner [teachings] say:
Taking blessings and abandoning evil is practicing the Dharma.
Merit refers to the fruits of merit.
The opponent says:
If merit refers to the fruits of merit, why does the Sutra on the Perfection of Wisdom only speak of merit?
The proponent of the doctrine says:
Merit refers to the cause, and the fruits of merit refer to the effect.
Sometimes the cause is spoken of as the effect, and sometimes the effect is spoken of as the cause. Here, the cause is spoken of as the effect.
It is like eating a thousand ounces of gold. The gold cannot be eaten, but because one obtains food by means of the gold, it is called eating gold.
It is also like seeing a painting and saying it is a good hand. Because one obtains the painting by means of the hand, it is called a good hand.
Attachment refers to clinging. The evil of clinging to the fruits of merit has already been explained.
Practice refers to that which always leads people to transmigrate in the cycle of birth and death.
The opponent says:
What are the dharmas that are not practiced?
The proponent of the doctrine says:
The Sutra on the Perfection of Wisdom speaks of both merit and demerit as well as their abandonment. Abandonment means the mind is not attached.
If the mind is not attached to merit, it will no longer go and come in the five destinies. This is called the dharma that is not practiced.
The opponent says:
One should not abandon merit, because its retribution is wonderful, and it is also not said to be cultivated for causes and conditions.
The fruits of all merits are wonderful. All sentient beings always seek wonderful fruits. How can they be abandoned?
Moreover, as the Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Do not fear merit.
You now do not speak of causes and conditions, therefore one should not abandon merit.
Internally, it is said:
When merit perishes, there is suffering.
Merit refers to meritorious retribution. Perishing means losing and destroying.
When meritorious retribution perishes, one is separated from delightful things and gives rise to great sorrow and suffering.
As the Buddha said:
Pleasant feelings are pleasant when arising and pleasant when abiding, but painful when ceasing.
Therefore, merit should be abandoned.
Moreover, when the Buddha said not to fear merit, it is because one should practice what aids the path.
As the Buddha said:
Merit should still be abandoned, let alone evil.
Externally, it is said:
Because evil and merit are mutually contradictory.
You say that when merit is exhausted, there is suffering. When sin arises and abides, it should be happiness.
Internally, it is said:
When sin abides, there is suffering.
Sin is called the retribution for sin. When the retribution for sin arises, there is suffering, let alone when it abides.
As the Buddha said:
When painful feelings arise, there is suffering. When they abide, there is suffering. When they cease, there is happiness.

You say that because sin and merit are mutually contradictory, when sin arises, it should be happiness. Now I will answer you. Why don't you say that because merit and sin are mutually contradictory, when merit ceases, it is happiness, and when it arises and abides, it is suffering?
Externally, it is said:
Because there are no conditions for abandoning permanent merit, it should not be abandoned.
You say that when the conditions for abandoning merit cease, there is suffering.
Now in the retribution for permanent merit, there is no suffering of cessation, so it should not be abandoned.
As the sutra says:
One who can perform the horse sacrifice transcends old age, death, and suffering. The retribution of merit is permanent, and the place of rebirth is permanent.
This merit should not be abandoned.
Internally, it is said:
Because merit has two aspects, it should be abandoned.
This merit has two aspects:
It can bring happiness and it can bring suffering.
Like poisoned rice, it tastes good when eaten but causes suffering when it is being digested.
Merit is also like this.
Moreover, some meritorious rewards are causes of happiness, but when received in excess, they become causes of suffering.
For example, when one is near a fire, it is pleasant to relieve the cold, but as one gets closer, it burns the body and causes suffering.
Therefore, merit has two aspects, and because it has two aspects, it is impermanent. For this reason, it should be abandoned.
Furthermore, you say that the rewards of the horse sacrifice are permanent, but this is mere words, because there is no reason.
The rewards of the horse sacrifice are actually impermanent.
Why is this?
Because the cause of the horse sacrifice karma is limited.
In the world, if the cause is limited, the effect is also limited.
For example, if the clay lump is small, the pot is also small.
Therefore, because the horse sacrifice karma is limited, it is impermanent.
Moreover, we hear that in your heavens there is anger, fighting, and mutual disturbance, so they should not be permanent.
Furthermore, the karma of horse sacrifices and so on arises from causes and conditions, so they are all impermanent.
Moreover, pure merit with outflows is impermanent, so it should be abandoned, let alone mixed merit and demerit.
For example, in the karma of horse sacrifices there is the sin of killing and so on.
Furthermore, as the Saá¹ƒkhya scriptures say, the method of sacrifice is impure, impermanent, and characterized by victory and defeat, so it should be abandoned.
The non-Buddhist says:
If merit is to be abandoned, one should not perform it.
If merit must be abandoned, it should not have been done in the first place. What wise person would create suffering for no reason?
It is like a potter making vessels only to break them again.
The Buddhist says:
The Dharma of the stages of the path of birth is like washing and dyeing a dirty garment.
Just as a dirty garment is first washed and then dyed when it is clean, washing it is not in vain.
Why is this?
Because defiled dharmas follow in sequence, and because a dirty cloth does not accept dye.
In this way, one first removes sinful defilements, then perfumes the mind with merit, and then accepts the dye of the path to nirvana.
The non-Buddhist says:
On what basis does one abandon merit and cultivate the path?
One abandons evil based on merit, but on what basis does one abandon merit?
The Buddhist says:
The markless is supreme.
One who grasps at merit is born among humans and gods, and one who grasps at sin is born in the three evil destinies. Therefore, the wisdom of the markless is the foremost.
The markless is called not recollecting any marks, being free from all feelings, and the mind being unattached to past, future, and present dharmas.
Because the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is nonexistent, there is nothing to rely on. This is called the markless.
By means of this skillful means, one is able to abandon merit.
Why is this?
Apart from the three gates of liberation, the foremost benefit cannot be attained.
As the Buddha said to the bhiká¹£us:

If someone says, 'I do not use emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, but wish to attain knowledge and insight without the conceit of superiority,' this person's words are empty and without substance.
Chapter 2: Refuting the Soul. The outsider says:
One should not say that all dharmas are empty and signless, because the soul and other dharmas exist.
KÄpila, Åªluka, and others say:
The soul and all dharmas exist.
KÄpila says:

From the primordial darkness, consciousness arises. From consciousness, the self-mind arises. From the self-mind, the five subtle elements arise. From the five subtle elements, the five gross elements arise. From the five gross elements, the eleven sense organs arise.
The soul is the master, permanent, characterized by consciousness, neutral, eternal, indestructible, imperishable, and embraces all dharmas.
One who knows these twenty-five tattvas attains liberation;
One who does not know them is not free from birth and death.
Åªluka says:
The existence of a real, eternal soul is known through the characteristics of inhalation and exhalation, seeing, blinking, lifespan, etc.
Moreover, it is known that there is a soul because it is the basis of desire, anger, suffering, pleasure, wisdom, etc.
Therefore, the soul truly exists. Why do you say it does not exist?
If one says non-existent where there is existence, one becomes a person of evil views. A person of evil views has no liberation.
Therefore, one should not say that all dharmas are empty and without characteristics.
The inner [opponent] says:
If one says non-existent where there is existence, this is an evil view.
If one says non-existent where there is non-existence, what is wrong with that?
Upon careful examination, there truly is no soul.
The outer [opponent] says:
The soul truly exists.
As the Saá¹ƒkhya scriptures say, the characteristic of awareness is the soul.
The inner [opponent] says:
Is the soul and awareness the same?
Or are they different?
The outer [opponent] says:
The soul and awareness are the same.
The inner [opponent] says:
If awareness is the characteristic of the soul, the soul is impermanent according to the Åšruti.
If cognition is the characteristic of the spirit, then because cognition is impermanent, the spirit should also be impermanent.
For example, heat is the characteristic of fire, and because heat is impermanent, fire is also impermanent.
Now, cognition is indeed impermanent.
Why is it so?
Because the characteristics are different, because it depends on causes and conditions, because it did not exist before but exists now, and because it existed but does not exist again.
The non-Buddhist says:
Because it does not arise, it is permanent.
The characteristic of arising is impermanent, but the spirit is not the characteristic of arising, so it is permanent.
The Buddhist says:
If so, cognition is not the characteristic of the spirit.
Cognition is impermanent, but you say the spirit is permanent. The spirit should be different from cognition.
If the spirit and cognition are not different, because cognition is impermanent, the spirit should also be impermanent.
Furthermore, if cognition is the characteristic of the spirit, this is not possible.
Why is it so?
Because cognition operates in one place.

If you say that consciousness is the characteristic of the spirit, then according to your doctrine, the spirit pervades everywhere, and consciousness should also function in the five destinies simultaneously;
yet consciousness functions in one place and cannot pervade everywhere. Therefore, consciousness is not the characteristic of the spirit.
Furthermore, if so, the spirit is equal to consciousness.
If you take consciousness as the characteristic of the spirit, the spirit should be equal to consciousness, and the spirit would not be pervasive.
Just as fire has no characteristic of heat or non-heat, the spirit is also like this, and should not have the characteristics of pervasiveness or non-pervasiveness.
Furthermore, if it is considered pervasive, then there is the characteristic of consciousness and non-consciousness.
If you want to make the spirit pervasive, the spirit would have two characteristics:
the characteristics of consciousness and non-consciousness.
Why is it so?
Because consciousness is not pervasive.
If the spirit falls into the place of consciousness, then it is consciousness; if it falls into the place of non-consciousness, then it is non-consciousness.
The opponent says:
There is no fault because the power is pervasive.
Although there is no function of cognition in some places, there is still the power of cognition here. Therefore, there is no fault of no cognition.
Internally, it is said:
This is not so.
Because the power and the powerful are not different.
If there is the power of cognition in a place, then cognition should have a function there but does not. Therefore, your statement is not correct.
If you say that even where cognition is without function, there is still the power of cognition, then this is just a statement.

If the pot is not different from the five parts of color, sound, smell, taste, and touch, then it should not be said to be one pot.
If it is said to be one pot, then color, etc. should also be one, because color, etc. are not different from the pot.
The opponent says:
Like an army and a forest.

The same is so for an army.
It is not that a single color is called a vase, nor is a vase apart from color.
The inner [school] says:
The many are also like a vase.
If pine and cypress trees are not different from the forest, one should not say one forest.
If one says one forest, pine and cypress trees should also be one, because they are not different from the forest.
Like the roots, trunk, branches, nodes, flowers, and leaves of a pine tree, one should also refute them in this way.
Like the army and all other things, one should refute them all in this way.
The outer [school] says:
Because many vases are received.
You say that the parts of color, etc. are many.

The inner [school] says:
It is not because color, etc. are many that the vase is many.

The opponent says:

Moreover, the color, etc. jar causes are the effect of the subtle particles. Because you accept color, etc., cause and effect are both established.
The proponent of the treatise says:
If the effect does not exist, the cause also does not exist.
Just as the jar is not different from the many parts such as color, etc., the jar should not be one.
Now color, etc. and the many parts are not different from the jar, so color, etc. should not be many.

Moreover, as for your statement that there is no cause without an effect, now because the effect is destroyed, the cause is also destroyed by itself. This is because in your doctrine, cause and effect are one.
Moreover, the three times are one.

If cause and effect are one, then the lump of clay should contain the pot and earth. Therefore, the three times are one.
The statements already done, doing now, and will do are destroyed.
